findings.author: alex_prompter
findings.text:
I genuinely think most JSON prompt tutorials are written by people who never shipped production code.

These 12 patterns handle:

‚Üí Malformed inputs
‚Üí Edge cases
‚Üí Scale (tested on 500K+ API calls)
‚Üí

findings.author: alex_prompter
findings.text:
11. CONFIDENCE SCORING OVERLAY

"For extracted data, add confidence:
{
  "name": "John Smith",
  "name_confidence": 0.95,
  "email": "john@example.com",
  "email_confidence": 0.62
}

Score 0.0-1.0. Be

findings.author: alex_prompter
findings.text:
10. BATCH PROCESSING CONSISTENCY

"Process items independently. One item's failure does not stop others.

Return:
{
  "results": [
    {"id": 1, "status": "success", "data": {...}},
    {"id": 2, "sta

findings.author: alex_prompter
findings.text:
8. LENGTH CONSTRAINT BOUNDARIES

"Each field has MAX length. Truncate intelligently if needed:

description: 500 chars max (end with ...)
title: 100 chars max (end at word boundary)
tags: array max 10

findings.author: alex_prompter
findings.text:
7. UNICODE & SPECIAL CHARACTER ARMOR

"Preserve all Unicode characters exactly as they appear. Do not:

- Convert accented characters (caf√© stays caf√©, not cafe)
- Escape quotes unless in JSON string

findings.author: alex_prompter
findings.text:
6. ENUMERATION LOCKDOWN

"status must be exactly one of: ['pending', 'active', 'completed', 'failed']

No variations. No capitalization changes. No synonyms.

If uncertain, use 'pending'.

CORRECT: "s

findings.author: alex_prompter
findings.text:
3. ARRAY CONSISTENCY LOCK

"Always return an array, even for single items. Empty results = empty array [].

CORRECT: [{"item": "x"}]
WRONG: {"item": "x"}

CORRECT: []
WRONG: null or "no results found"

findings.author: alex_prompter
findings.text:
1. SCHEMA-FIRST ENFORCEMENT

Instead of: "Return JSON with name and email"

Use this:

"Return ONLY valid JSON matching this exact schema. No markdown, no explanation, no extra fields:
{
  "name": "st

findings.author: alex_prompter
findings.text:

Not the theoretical stuff you see in tutorials.

Real prompts that handle edge cases, weird inputs, and don't break when
